parameterized_text: Task: In the course "[[Course]]" view the page titled "[[Page]]" by navigating to the Pages Index and selecting the page from the list. Return the contents of the page body.

instances.instance_text: Task: In the course "Speculative Design for Public Futures 318" view the page titled "Speculative Policy Prototyping Workshop" by navigating to the Pages Index and selecting the page from the list. Return the contents of the page body.

answer_key.Text:
This page describes the Speculative Policy Prototyping Workshop for Speculative Design for Public Futures 318
The workshop goal is to practice design led approaches for imagining and testing policy interventions that respond to public challenges. Students will learn methods for rapid policy sketching, narrative prototyping, and low fidelity testing with community personas to surface unintended consequences and power dynamics.
Format and schedule - Three live sessions plus an asynchronous sprint. Session 1 - Framing constraints and norm mapping; Session 2 - Prototyping techniques and peer testing; Session 3 - Public feedback simulation and final pitches. Asynchronous work includes research, prototype development, and a reflective journal entry between sessions.
Core activities - Rapid policy sketching and policy artifact creation; Scenario mapping and impact ladders; Persona based role play and tabletop testing; Creation of tangible engagement assets such as visual briefs, mock public notices, and short performative scripts to surface public responses.
Deliverables and assessment - Team submission of two artifacts: a concise speculative policy brief and a prototype engagement asset. Assessment split includes peer feedback for 20 percent, instructor evaluation for 50 percent, and the reflective journal for 30 percent. Rubrics focus on plausibility, ethical reflection, clarity of public benefit, and attention to equity.
Ethical guidance - Prototypes must avoid causing harm and must surface who benefits and who may be disadvantaged. Each submission needs a mitigation plan for potential harms and a plan for consent and data minimization when testing with people.
Sample LMS discussion excerpt - Instructor - Please document key assumptions behind your prototypes and test them with at least two distinct community perspectives. Student A - We are prototyping a skills linked basic support policy and want feedback on how to make trade offs legible. Student B - Consider a pilot metric set that centers lived experience and access rather than only economic outputs. Instructor - Strong idea, draft a short evaluation plan before the next session for peer review.
Support and logistics - Virtual office hours Thursdays 3 to 4 PM and by appointment. Upload draft artifacts to the workshop folder by Friday midnight to allow time for peer review and instructor comments.

instances.instance_text: Task: In the course "Urban Agroecology and Food Systems 341" view the page titled "Urban Soil Health and Community Food Networks" by navigating to the Pages Index and selecting the page from the list. Return the contents of the page body.

mapping.Page: Urban Soil Health and Community Food Networks

answer_key.Text: Urban soil health is foundational to resilient city food systems and depends on rigorous, place based research and inclusive stewardship. Soil science approaches such as systematic soil testing, profile description, and biological assays guide practices for building organic matter, enhancing nutrient cycling, and managing contaminant riskespecially in older urban neighborhoods. Community engaged methods combine participatory mapping, garden sampling, and open data sharing to center local knowledge and promote equitable access to safe growing spaces. Restoration techniques like composting, cover cropping, phytoremediation, and reduced tillage support soil structure and microbial diversity while reducing reliance on external chemical inputs. Linking soil stewardship to community food networks strengthens local distribution, supports culturally relevant diets, and builds collective capacity for food sovereignty. Municipal policy, accessible training, and targeted remediation funding are essential to scale evidence based interventions and protect public health from untested or well meaning but potentially harmful practices

instances.instance_text: Task: In the course "Quantum Materials and Nanostructures 412" view the page titled "Topological Quantum Materials and Nanofabrication" by navigating to the Pages Index and selecting the page from the list. Return the contents of the page body.

answer_key.Text:
Topological quantum materials are defined by global properties of their electronic band structure that produce protected surface or edge modes that are robust against weak disorder and perturbations
This page introduces topological insulators topological semimetals and topological superconductors with emphasis on the physical concepts of Berry curvature band inversion and bulk boundary correspondence
We review experimental platforms and nanofabrication routes used to realize and probe these phases including molecular beam epitaxy electron beam lithography focused ion beam atomic layer deposition and dry etching for device patterning
Characterization techniques covered include angle resolved photoemission spectroscopy scanning tunneling microscopy quantum transport measurements and transmission electron microscopy with attention to sample preparation and cryogenic measurement methods
Lab and cleanroom best practices are described with guidance on contamination control glove use hazardous material handling and reproducibility in nanofabrication workflows
Applications such as fault tolerant qubits topological spintronics and low dissipation electronics are discussed along with current challenges like disorder induced localization and interfacing topological materials with superconductors
Students are expected to engage with recent literature bring design proposals for nanodevices and participate in hands on fabrication and measurement sessions

instances.instance_text: Task: In the course "Astrobiology Field Methods and Planetary Habitability 301" view the page titled "Astrobiology Field Techniques and Habitability Assessment" by navigating to the Pages Index and selecting the page from the list. Return the contents of the page body.

mapping.Course: Astrobiology Field Methods and Planetary Habitability 301
mapping.Page: Astrobiology Field Techniques and Habitability Assessment

answer_key.Text: Astrobiology combines field based investigation with laboratory analysis to evaluate the potential for life in planetary environments. Field methods emphasize careful site selection, sterile sampling, in situ measurement, and comprehensive metadata collection. Instruments range from handheld spectrometers and microscopes to drilling rigs and environmental sensors required for geochemical profiling and biosignature detection. Strict contamination control and planetary protection protocols preserve sample integrity and prevent forward contamination. Results are validated through reproducible workflows, cross disciplined collaboration, and peer reviewed publication to separate robust evidence from speculation. Mastery of these techniques allows students to assess habitability using observational constraints, thermodynamic limits, and ecological analogs on Earth

instances.instance_text: Task: In the course "Computational Neuroethology and Animal Behavior 477" view the page titled "Neural Circuits in Natural Behavior" by navigating to the Pages Index and selecting the page from the list. Return the contents of the page body.

answer_key.Text: Understanding how neural circuits generate natural behavior is a core concern of Computational Neuroethology and Animal Behavior 477. This page summarizes experimental and computational strategies for linking neurons and networks to ethologically relevant actions. Topics include in vivo electrophysiology, calcium imaging, targeted perturbations using optogenetics and chemogenetics, and anatomical mapping with modern connectomic approaches. We emphasize studying behavior in naturalistic contexts, extracting kinematic and pose features with automated tracking, and building dynamical models that predict decision making and motor sequences. Practical modules will cover preprocessing of neural and behavioral data, model fitting, cross validation, and interpretation of circuit level mechanisms. The page also addresses reproducibility, data sharing, and ethical considerations for research with live animals to promote rigorous and responsible science.

instances.instance_text: Task: In the course "Museum Robotics and Artifact Conservation 347" view the page titled "Robotic Systems for Artifact Preservation" by navigating to the Pages Index and selecting the page from the list. Return the contents of the page body.

answer_key.Text: Robotic systems for artifact preservation combine precision engineering with conservation science to support the long term care of museum collections. They encompass autonomous mobile platforms for continuous environmental monitoring, compliant robotic arms for delicate handling and localized treatments, and non contact imaging such as 3D scanning and multispectral photography for condition assessment. These tools improve repeatability of inspections, reduce physical risk to fragile objects, and enable interventions in confined or hazardous areas while preserving human oversight. Effective use depends on close collaboration between conservators, curators, and engineers to ensure mechanical actions respect material sensitivity and historical context. The course emphasizes validation, ethical practice, and documentation so that robotic interventions are reversible, minimally invasive, and fully recorded. Topics include sensor fusion, compliant control strategies, data management for long term monitoring, and case studies demonstrating successful robotic conservation projects

instances.instance_text: Task: In the course "Cinematic Sound Design for Interactive Storytelling 327" view the page titled "Spatial Audio Techniques for Interactive Storytelling" by navigating to the Pages Index and selecting the page from the list. Return the contents of the page body.

mapping.Course: Cinematic Sound Design for Interactive Storytelling 327
mapping.Page: Spatial Audio Techniques for Interactive Storytelling

answer_key.Text: Spatial audio is essential for crafting immersive moments in interactive storytelling. This page summarizes practical techniques for spatializing sound in games and narrative projects, focusing on perceptual clarity and adaptive workflows. Covered topics include ambisonics and binaural rendering, head related transfer function approaches and their approximations, realtime spatialization inside popular engines, and audio middleware integration with FMOD and Wwise. We outline strategies for mixing in dynamic scenes where listener position and camera control change over time, plus methods for simulating room acoustics and occlusion in interactive contexts. Performance considerations address cpu budgets, level of detail for distant sources, and batching to reduce overhead. Hands on exercises will guide you through creating spatial mixes, performing listening tests on headphones and multichannel setups, and iterating based on player feedback. Links to sample plugins, reference projects, and further readings are provided for continued study

instances.instance_text: Task: In the course "Forensic Linguistics and Legal Discourse 314" view the page titled "Forensic Linguistics Casework and Courtroom Discourse" by navigating to the Pages Index and selecting the page from the list. Return the contents of the page body.

mapping.Page: Forensic Linguistics Casework and Courtroom Discourse

answer_key.Text:
Forensic linguistics applies linguistic theory and empirical methods to the analysis of language related evidence
   in legal and investigative contexts. Analysts examine patterns of lexis and grammar to address questions of
   authorship attribution, document authenticity, and the wording of confessions or threats. Methods range from
   corpus driven comparisons and computational stylometry to careful phonetic analysis of recorded speech,
   always paired with explicit statements about uncertainty and scope of inference. Courtroom discourse is
   treated as a distinct communicative environment shaped by procedural norms role relations and strategic
   interactional moves among judge counsel witness and jurors. Good practice emphasizes transparent methodology
   preservation of original materials clear reporting of limitations and a commitment to ethical handling of
   sensitive evidence to support fair and reliable decision making in legal settings

instances.instance_text: Task: In the course "Climate Finance and Green Bond Markets 428" view the page titled "Climate Finance and Green Bond Fundamentals" by navigating to the Pages Index and selecting the page from the list. Return the contents of the page body.

mapping.Course: Climate Finance and Green Bond Markets 428
mapping.Page: Climate Finance and Green Bond Fundamentals

answer_key.Text: Climate finance mobilizes public and private capital to support low carbon and climate resilient development.  Green bonds are debt instruments that finance projects with clear environmental benefits and often include use of proceeds restrictions, independent verification, and ongoing reporting.  Key fundamentals include project eligibility, alignment with green taxonomies, third party certification, and robust impact metrics that enable transparency and investor confidence.  Market participants range from sovereign and municipal issuers to development banks and corporations each facing trade offs between cost of capital and credibility.  Investors evaluate credit risk, climate related transition and physical risks, and the integrity of labeling to avoid greenwashing.  Policy frameworks taxation incentives and standardised disclosure regimes play a central role in scaling issuance and improving market liquidity.  Case studies and empirical evidence help students assess pricing, additionality, and the real world outcomes of green bond financing.  This page provides an overview of concepts methodologies and practical tools for analysing green bond instruments within the broader climate finance landscape.

instances.instance_text: Task: In the course "Ethical Hacking and Civic Cybersecurity 304" view the page titled "Responsible Disclosure and Bug Bounty Practices" by navigating to the Pages Index and selecting the page from the list. Return the contents of the page body.

mapping.Page: Responsible Disclosure and Bug Bounty Practices

answer_key.Text:
This page defines responsible disclosure and bug bounty practices for Ethical Hacking and Civic Cybersecurity 304. It sets expectations for authorized testing, safe proof of concept development, concise reporting, legal considerations, and coordination with vendors and incident response teams. Adhering to these practices protects students, researchers, and community partners and reinforces ethical and civic minded security work.
Guiding principles and rules
- Obtain explicit authorization before testing any system or service
- Limit testing to agreed scope and avoid collateral impact on third party users
- Do not exfiltrate or retain sensitive data and avoid destructive techniques such as denial of service
- Avoid social engineering and physical intrusion unless explicitly permitted
Reporting expectations
- Provide a short summary of the issue and its practical impact on users or services
- Include clear reproduction steps and a minimal proof of concept
- Describe root cause analysis and suggested remediation or mitigation steps
- Estimate severity and potential mitigations based on risk to civic infrastructure
Timelines and disclosure
- Report issues privately to the responsible party and course staff when relevant
- Allow a standard remediation window of 90 days before public disclosure unless urgent risk requires earlier action
- Coordinate public disclosure to ensure fixes are available and to prevent harm
Recognition and rewards
- Researchers who follow these practices will be acknowledged in a manner agreed with the affected party
- Bug bounties or course credit may be awarded based on impact and quality of the report
Legal and safety notes
- Ensure your work complies with applicable laws and the institution code of conduct
- If in doubt seek prior approval from course instructors or legal advisors
Contact and escalation
- Use the official course reporting channel to submit findings and to request safe harbor or authorization
- In emergencies contact the instructor and the campus security team for coordinated response
Following these guidelines helps build trust between researchers and defenders and supports responsible, civic focused cybersecurity scholarship

instances.instance_text: Task: View the comments left by your instructor (Lina Morales) on your "Edible Landscaping Case Study" assignment in the "Urban Agroecology and Food Systems 341" course. What was the feedback Lina Morales gave you?

answer_key.Text: Well organized submission that ties practical design decisions to agroecological theory. Your sketch and plant list were informative and the soil rebuilding plan is realistic. For a higher score include more precise yield calculations with sources, and a clearer timeline for volunteer training and seasonal tasks.

instances.instance_text: Task: View the comments left by your instructor (Dr Rajesh Iyer) on your "Defect Engineering in Semiconductors Essay" assignment in the "Quantum Materials and Nanostructures 412" course. What was the feedback Dr Rajesh Iyer gave you?

instances.instance_text: Task: View the comments left by your instructor (Dr Dina Rutherford) on your "Neuroethology Literature Synthesis" assignment in the "Computational Neuroethology and Animal Behavior 477" course. What was the feedback Dr Dina Rutherford gave you?

answer_key.Text: Strong synthesis that connects methods and findings across systems. Your proposed hybrid experiment is well motivated. For a higher score, add more detail on specific analytic pipelines and on how you would operationalize causal perturbations and statistical tests.

instances.instance_text: Task: View the comments left by your instructor (Amelia Santos) on your "Emergency Response Robotics Scenario" assignment in the "Museum Robotics and Artifact Conservation 347" course. What was the feedback Amelia Santos gave you?

answer_key.Text: Strong practical plan with clear links to conservation priorities Consider adding a short appendix that lists sensor models and calibration procedures

instances.instance_text: Task: View the comments left by your instructor (Celia Moreno) on your "Synthesized SFX for Fantasy Interactions" assignment in the "Cinematic Sound Design for Interactive Storytelling 327" course. What was the feedback Celia Moreno gave you?

mapping.Course: Cinematic Sound Design for Interactive Storytelling 327

answer_key.Text: Strong technical choices and clear layering explanations. Your implementation notes are practical and the middleware mappings show good awareness of interactive needs. For further improvement include screenshots of your signal chain and a short table of parameter ranges for each exposed control. Also test memory usage on lower end devices and provide optimized builds of your stems.
